YRlNsOVOQRaqOYO03e1yHA.text: I used to rate Christopher's very highly however my last visit was not very pleasant. I believe the quality & service has went downhill. I came here for Thanksgiving- which i usually do. I found the staff not very friendly and the service incredibly rushed. From the moment we sat down our waiter wanted to know our entire order- once we gave it- he did not come back once to us the entire meal. It was difficult to get anyone's attention and everyone was rushing around. I ordered the vegetarian entree and it was very odd. It was advertised as celaric gumbo with jalapeno beignets & cornbread. Sounds filing enough... but when it came I was shocked to see the gumbo was no bigger than the size of a thimble put into a carved hole in the bottom of a courgette. The cornbread was hard and dry & a tiny cube. They then put cherry tomatos that were stuffed with rice around the courgette which contained a thimble sized portion of the gumbo. I was very unimpressed by the vegetarian entree, the taste, & my experience. My husband was pleased with the turkey entree but also felt the service and experience was so rushed that it became unpleasant.

-QZxWkGTr-DUDyVDodsvJg.text: I went here for brunch before the theatre and it was the perfect place to meet up as the show was just around the corner. Usually locations in the center of the theatre district can be hit or miss but this venue continues to surprise. It is American cuisine true and true so it is a great spot to hit up whenever I get a tadbit homesick. The portions here are proper American portions - nice and healthy! I had the blueberry pancakes which were delightful. My FI had the equivalent of what they call Juevos Rancheros in the states - he was pleased with his meal as well. My British friends noshed on Bloody Mary's and Steak and Eggs and the Parisians had the fig and cheese platter, hash browns and pancakes. All were happy and full by the end of the meal and delighted that they had found a new spot in town to frequent! The decor is also pleasing to the eye. Not too ornate but still enough pizzaz to give you the feeling like you are in a special place, not some chain food restaurant. We had some additions to our party at the last minute and they were quick and easy about accommodating us and because we were so close to the theatre we weren't rushed at all about finishing up our meal. I will definitely be going again.

WWKWpsXC7V-vKi_sTSkauA.text: I came here for their Thanksgiving dinner and it was pretty good. They served a classic American turkey, gravy, cranberry sauce type of meal. I happen to be sitting right near where Stephen Colbert was sitting with a group...I'm assuming he was being as patriotic as can be by having Thanksgiving in the only "American" restaurant in the city.   This restaurant has to be good if Stephen Colbert decides to grace with his presence?Really great bar area.

sf8Ju1Qwc7uV0Jyigo1GUw.text: Fantastic decor, especially downstairs in the bar. The steaks were ok but that's all you get and for the price, thats not a good deal. I've had steaks that were just as good elsewhere. The staff aren't friendly and ignore you. Way over priced, even for London.

dLvWc7E1k2EZJJYN7E8vqg.text: "American Grill" is an addendum that really ought to be read with apostrophes, or raised eyebrows: this is a restaurant with a finger in a good few cultural pies. The lounge bar on the ground floor is as bronzed and suave as a Max le Verrier model, with some rather swanky booths from which to peruse what is surely (assuming you like martinis) an embarras de richesse on the cocktail menu. On climbing a grand stone staircase -- lit all the way with tea-lights, and observed chubbily from the ceiling fresco by a handful of putti -- you reach a restaurant that resembles nothing more than a exquisite and high-ceilinged drawing room; testament, it appears [1], to the building's Victorian heritage. Service is friendly while by no means overbearing: staff are attentive, and the generous selection of home-made bread proffered on arrival was among the best I have experienced. The menu is as diverse as the restaurant's self-styled denomination of "modern American cuisine" might suggest; a definition so gloriously capacious as, ultimately, not to define very much at all. Lobsters flown in daily from New England sit comfortably alongside their sustainably-sourced Southern counterparts (blackened salmon with jambalaya risotto is one such offering), while the large selection of side-dishes unites a Mexican-inspired Monterey mash with the Southwest's endearingly named - and impeccably cooked - 'tobacco onions' and 'shoestring fries'. At the sizzling centre of the 'American Grill', of course, is steak - of which the restaurant is lavishly, and justifiably, proud. Cuts of 28 day-aged prime Scottish beef make up almost half of the main course selection, accompanied by lovingly-crafted tasting notes on the merits of marbling and the spare elegance of a fillet cut ("tenderness assured" [2]).The menu lapses in imagination - if not, usually, in the other kind of taste - when it seeks most to embody 'Americana': the quintessential, the retro, the downright whimsical. I can only assume that proximity to National Peach Melba Day in the USA (the thirteenth of January) prompted the inclusion of that dish in the dessert menu. I'm more ambivalent as regards the roast beet salad with chicory, ricotta, and cabernet vinaigrette, ordered as a main course from the starters menu. The main ingredient being a type of shredded lettuce notoriously to be found as a packing ingredient in burgers and burritos the world over, I must assume that the chef's aim here was, via the dual agency of ricotta and red wine vinegar, to rescue it from the opprobrium of tastelessness. It is perhaps the best -- if the most back-handed -- tribute of all to say that, being Christopher's, this roast beet ["hold the shredded lettuce"] salad managed to be as tasty as any salad I've ever ordered. Anywhere.[1] But not as a drawing room. The colourful history of this magnificent Grade II-listed building includes life as a papier mache factory, and,  after 1870, as London's first licensed casino.[2] Meanwhile, I was myself assured by my dining partner of the extent to which, as a vegetarian, I miss out on the delights of combining a Christopher's medium grilled rib-eye with a glass of good pinot noir (surprisingly good value at less than £25 a bottle).

VODXX0wHKOYEStmS83Cjfw.text: This is situated in the heart of the city just o the side of Covent Garden.I recently went to a birthday party here- it would never be my first choice of place -as it is rather corporate and bland --But  we had a private room downstairs with our own reception,cloakroom and bathroom which was really nice.Although the restaurants atmosphere was not too exciting the service was amazing and personel- the wine was good - and the place was great for meeting old friends without distraction.So I was unduly impressed --the place was great for the occasion and a great success.

Wf70sJAfOkQgcvPUs8zxJg.text: One of my favourite place for a business meeting in town. Old school surroundings, decent service, good food and a nice range of wines and cocktails. Marvellous place to while away an afternoon if the lunch meeting spreads out a bit. The atmosphere is great - lots of chat going on, but enough space between the tables so that you can have a decent discussion without having to raise your voice at all. Highly recommended for lunches and a nice cocktail bar downstairs for your evening do to roll on a little further. Perhaps a little 'suity' at but not enough to put you off. Highly recommended.

VPqwc3D9e3kuXkmkQUlFVg.text: I went here for a recent company dinner. We used the private room downstairs that has its own bar and lounge area. Our company staff and guests really enjoyed the place in terms of food and decor. On the down-side service was a bit ditzy and the steak wasn't actually that good (I realise that perhaps with the 12 people who ordered the kitchen is under pressure, but there was a fair amount of tough fat and sinew on what was meant to be a prime cut). The wine menu is fine, although be careful with the staff recommendations. They really need perhaps need someone with a bit more experience doing this. Good thing we had a senior member of staff who collects the stuff and changed the set-wines straight away! Upstairs was nice, reception is for want of a better word 'posh'. As someone mentioned it is kinda 'suity' and I wouldn't go here except for company things. For steak restaurants, Gaucho's or Smiths' of Smithfield is a far better choice. However for privacy and the good atmosphere this did in-fact beat Smiths. Overall 3 stars, for the price I would've expected the food to be better.

e89Qve0EkLTEcWyvElQlBg.text: On my recent jaunt to back to London, my palate was refreshed with multiple nouveau martinis at Christophers in Covent Garden. Bombay Basil, French Apple and Passionfruit Bellinis - just three of the extensive and biblical list of cocktails. Friendly staff and an oozingly seductive decor - welcome to my new secret rendez vous on the Piccadilly Line.

0a5kjBLNlxgupfuJ9Nl2yA.text: First impressions- Very nice decor and polite and friendly staff. However..I found the food to be overpriced, underflavoured with ridiculous sized portions. Any one looking for a good, hearty meal, forget it. The walnut bread was nice though.. one tiny slice (if you can call it that, more of a sliver).

yZzPG3blK57fVCS22HcrDQ.text: This our third visit to Christophers and unfortunately it was a disappointment this time. We started off in the Martini Bar and that was excellent. The barman was fantastic and I would recommend the bar without doubt. The restaurant was upstairs and I feel that the menu choice was limited this time but this could be just me! The starters and desserts were lovely but the main courses were disappointing. Hubby had steak - carpetbag and I had pidgeon - both unfortunately were just average and for me overpriced for the quality. All in all, I would recommend the Martini Bar but we probably won't be going back to the restaurant again.

EByhzmP4k8pw9LlJX0yZXg.text: Charming old school restaurant in Covent Garden. Great place for formal entertaining or something a bit special. Food is always excellent and the drinks - from cocktails to wine menu are spot on.

ynuP-LZZFE6hJdFcMUiOkA.text: Tried a little too hard to be an old-school steakhouse.  Food wasn't bad, but not memorable.  Service wasn't bad, but not great.  A little slow.  Very staid room and feel.  For the price, I'd go elsewhere.

rdo1ShDzFQD-LpPoW80EYA.text: Service was a little haphazard. Pre dinner drinks were slow to arrive then the starters arrived about 3 minutes after ordering. Would have preferred things a little more spaced out and even. However the quality of food was great. Carpaccio to start followed by a delicious grilled lobster.

v0_obq2mPlpnuLFX3u5nLQ.text: As an American I give this place 5 stars! American food through and through! I ate here twice during my vacation. The prices are steep, but so is 90% of London! The first floor features a beautiful NYC type of bar. Great for for that drink before dinner. Go up the beautiful staircase and enjoy the quiet upscale dining room! Service and food were top notch! Highly recommend!

D1LY-OUNwmK8JasxtKwySg.text: Not what we expected of a "martini" bar!  Got a dirty martini with Grey goose vodka but it was more dirty than vodka.  Glasses were small and had little alcohol.   My wife had an Almond cigar and it was too sweet and again no alcohol.  Terrible experience.

2hQDZEs7cQipBi19hYvchw.text: Awesome food and service.  Blackened Salmon, Ribeye and Cesar salad are wonderful.  We will be back.  Service was attentive and just the right pace.

fYRqAVujORN6N1akkk0V-Q.text: After a night out, in Britain there is the kebab shop.  In the states, some may opt for Taco Bell, but sometimes, what you really need is a short stack of pancakes with a side of extra bacon (streaky bacon) at IHOP (or Denny's...whichever you prefer).  And that is exactly why we tried out Christopher's American Grill on a Saturday morning.The exterior is certainly impressive and I began to think that maybe I was underdressed for our pancake experience, but that really wasn't going to stop me.  I was rather surprised that there were not more people in the restaurant when we arrived.  However, I was glad because it meant we were seated quickly.  We ordered our drinks and I chose to go with the filtered coffee.  It smelled lovely and it had this very creamy texture to it...  and that was before I added milk.I was torn...  they have a part of the menu called 'Pancakes and Such' and I couldn't make a decision!  They had regular buttermilk pancakes with maple syrup and maple cured bacon or they had blueberry pancakes, but no side of bacon.  And then...  they had french toast, with roasted peaches!  If there is one thing I love more than pancakes... it is french toast.  In the end it came down to the fact that my original mission was pancakes...  and the tipping point was the maple cured bacon.  My friend and her sister ordered the blueberry pancakes and the eggs benedict.Our food came in good time and the staff were very attentive.  The pancakes looked delicious... although probably the fanciest plate of pancakes I have ever had.  There were three pancakes, but I would say that they were more like silver dollar pancakes...  admittedly I could've had another plate because I was feeling that greedy.  The pancakes were delicious and the warm maple syrup was a very nice touch.  And the bacon!  It wasn't streaky bacon, however there was not much fat on them, and they were cooked more on the well done side...  just before crispy, but still had a nice dark colour to it.  The bacon had wonderful flavour.  My meal was just over £10 and I thought it was very reasonable for the delicious pancakes and bacon.I will probably go back to test out the french toast...  stay tuned for that!

j5qdUrhlfUADX1w4ewPujA.text: I've only been here for brunch (twice) and it has been amaaazing. I had chocolate waffle and ice cream (don't judge me!) and fruit juice. It was one of the most indulgent breakfasts I've ever had. My brother had pancakes (delicious) and eggs benedict (he wouldn't let me try any haha!). The coffee is also really nice though I'm not a coffee expert! The staff are generally nice (theres always an exception) and its a little pricey but the rooms are nicely decorated and looks good so it levels out I think. Give it a go!

bV9xrXoFSHAobnOBdtYIaQ.text: Popped into Christopher's for Sunday brunch about a week ago and was pleasantly surprised. I'd passed the edifice en route to my local Tesco but had no idea what lie inside. As many have noted, the ambiance is really beautiful. High ceilings, beautiful fixtures and impeccable service. I had the french toast (my brunch go-to) and it was probably the best that I've had in London thus far. I definitely will be back.

hhXa8n9L8676gfnHoPpFNg.text: Great drinks and and even better company. Bartender David is classically creative and attention to details. Fantastic experience!

DUspqyJIzNLyUsKCB9rs_A.text: I love the cocktail bar here! Lots of very naughty martinis in a relatively serene setting. If you can, snag a booth and work your way through the martini menu from the 'refreshing' to the 'sinful'! My favourites at the two ends of the scale are the chilli cucumber and the naughty chocolate! Service is quick and friendly, prices are astronomical, but hey, it's an oasis in covent garden!

89Iv5olaij9lDkroZmFg-w.text: Nice ambiance. Came for brunch in a Sunday so the choices were a little limited. Had the hue is rancheros which is some eggs and avocado on salsa and cheese. It had a bit of a kick to it but I was a bit overwhelmed with the cheese. They also have a bar if you want to just drop in.

h6NzXPNJpPIFtGxVbRsAfw.text: I want to be clear, the service kept this establishment from being a 5 star restaurant.  The food itself was absolutely delicious.We arrived on time for our 8:15pm reservation and checked in at the front desk.  The hostess informed us that the table was held for us and we could have a drink at the bar if we wanted to.  We opted for this and got two beefeater martinis, extra dirty, extra dry, up with olives.  The bartender actually muddled olives and strained them out when pouring the drink as opposed to using olive juice.  Big points for that.When we finally sat, we got a nice bottle of Merlot-Tempranillo and began with the scallops appetizer.  These little marshmallows of the sea were cooked perfectly and dressed with truffle oil which make them heavenly.  Our waiter was quite slow in bringing out our bottle of wine and this was the first indication that we might have an issue.When our steaks arrived, only one of the sides showed up, the asparagus with watercress and truffle oil.  When my buddy inquired about his onions, the waiter said he would check on them.  We ended up asking him again about the onions when were were mostly through our meal, around 10 minutes later.  They finally came flying out of the kitchen as we neared the end of our steaks.  There was clearly a timing issue here.We ended up splitting the panna cotta for dessert and ordered two glasses of port.  The dessert arrived promptly but once again, our port was brought significantly after the dessert arrived, almost when we were done consuming it.At a less costly restaurant, I would overlook things of this nature but I feel at this price point and for this quality of food, the service needs to be at a similarly high level.  It wasn't unfortunately and so the 3 star rating.  To be fair, my steak was fantastic and all the food we tasted was awesome.

M-VZXr2cY3pkcht3s5cZUA.text: Had yet another lovely meal at Christophers. Always enjoy their brunch and went for lunch.Unfortunately there was a very loud business lunch going on with 2 men guffawing at everything which, while they were there, was not very good.However the food was excellent and I would certainly recommend the Grilled Asparagus with Pecorino Cheese & Truffle Oil as a starter. while the Gressingham duck was pink and tender. The sweet potato mash was a perfect side order. Spent a long afternoon over coffee after the meeting crowd moved on.Will be trying them out for dinner soon.

hST0MSVR9Nb0wulWZ8RD3w.text: Review just for the bar:I had very high expectations. For drinks, they were met. For atmosphere, it was a total let down. The dirty martinis were well done, and the smokey martini (splash of single-malt) had me completely won over. Three stars for the place, five for the drinks.

hNLnXGW56MZEnByqwWrweA.text: Amazing brunch. The service is great. We tried the egg white omelette, the salad and the macaroni cheese lobster and everything was top if the line.

M-a4GHrKk8bZew6z_fl8Ew.text: Being an American myself, I didn't find anything distinctively American about this restaurant and bar, but I did enjoy my visit here. The bartenders are extremely skilled and as a fellow bartender, quite inspiring to watch. Walking into the Martini Bar is like walking into a posh, exclusive club with its lush leather booths, leather covered barstools, and strong drinks that are beautifully made. It was really crowded the night we were there but it didn't feel squashed or too crowded, there was still room to move around and enough seating for almost everyone. Definitely a great bar if you're looking for a higher end bar to catch some drinks before or after dinner and a great location too.

ItukocAw1KdUpkefcfuFjQ.text: While I was visiting London - I met some friends at Christopher's for Sunday brunch - what a great brunch spot!  We sat upstairs where they have a larger dining room (which was really crowded) and a smaller side dining room that has a great view of the theater area. I'm not sure if this is a pricey dinner place - but it was pretty affordable for brunch.  They have all the traditional brunch fare - eggs, pancakes, healthy granola stuff, etc and plenty of bloody marys and mimosas to start your morning off right. The juices were really really good - fresh squeezed orange juice - none of the icky made from concentrate stuff.I shared steak and eggs and the watermelon/blueberry/spinach salad with my friend - all of it was delicious and large portions.  Service was excellent - definitely a place I would come again!

jfdfn28bBRPX25PwOm3bag.text: We went to Christopher's before a play and chose the set menu. We each had something different and all of us loved it. Presentation was spectacular and taste superb. We would recommend to anyone and everyone. Specifically try the warm goat cheese salad.

_tBr4B627I0ULLldpDDRhA.text: Hmmm, foood, we all love a nice bit of greasy fatty food sometimeChristopher's is an American-style restaurant that is popular with meat lovers due to its choice of grills. It has a buzzing atmosphere and is great fun for everyone if your by yourself ,with friends, or if you feel like a nice day / night out with the family!. Christopher's is a licensed bar and they also have outside catering and cater for vegetarians. Catering for private parties of up to 200 guests is available upon request.Is i always say you always need a lot of money if you plan to go out to eat or drink in the west end as it can get very pricey, but if your looking to fill your belly this is the one.

photos.caption: Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom

IBT20c86L0nGh3MpxXlBCQ.text: **DISCLAIMER: I've only been to the bar, not the restaurant upstairs**This is a fairly swanky bar with a fantastic cocktail menu. Moreover, the bartenders (not the waiters, alas) know pretty much every cocktail ever made, so don't be afraid to order off the menu too.The first time I came here, the bar staff let my party stay quite late (it was a Monday night) before asking us politely to leave. The second time, the bar staff remembered me and managed to find me a table even though it was busy. They even remembered how much I liked dirty vodka martinis, which I thought was a nice touch. Most recently I went with a close gal pal; two of the bar staff came over and greeted us immediately, went out of their way to find us a table (it was a Friday night, prime after-work drinking hours), and one of them gave me a two-for-one loyalty card.The service, as you can tell, is brilliant, and the cocktails aren't bad either. This isn't the sort of place I would come with a large group, because the bar is often quite busy and tables seem to be reserved far far in advance. It is, however, a great location, and the cocktails deserve their price tag. Nice for a quick after-work drink, or a romantic cuddle with a friend (mood-lighting a-plenty).

56pL85x3MygtWlceLkguUQ.text: I've got to thank Volkswagen for bringing Christopher's to my attention as they sent me tickets for a deluxe dinner and theatre experience earlier in the year, but I have only got around to using it. Well both son and daughter getting married in the same year (bailiffs due anytime now) but i digress, back to Christopher's, it coincided with our wedding anniversary so i thought what a nice treat for us and as usual, we arrived in plenty of time to allow pre dinner drinks, so into the cocktail bar we went, ordering a large G&T for my wife and a large Drambuie for myself, just to wet our appetites. I suggested that we try a cocktail, as they looked and sounded rather tasty. Not being a great lover of, spirits, but a great chocoholic, i was drawn to the Nutella Martini, consisting of Vanilla Vodka, Creme de Cacao, Cream, Nutella (of course) & shaved chocolate. This is how adults should take chocolate, in liquid form and with a smooth, but strong alcoholic kick, this was followed by a Caramel Heart Martini and a Chili & Chocolate Martini, (I did say i was a chocoholic)! Our appetites suitably wet we went upstairs for our dinner. The dinning area isn't that large, neither is is too small, but found it to provide diners with sufficient elbow and seating room. As we had opted for the pre theatre menu, we weren't expecting much in either taste or portions, but we were wrong, opting for the two course menu, our choices of smoked tomato soup with basil oil, cod cake with rocket & Harissa remoulade for our first course was found to be quite amazing as it there was so much flavour packed into such small portions, the main meal of Grilled '100 Day Aged' BBQ Rubbed Bavette of Beef with Grilled Tomatoes & Chunky Chips, was equally amazing and left a nice spicy bite at the back of our mouths. Cant fault the service, as our hostess and waiters were very professional and helpful, without being intrusive. I would recommend that if your in their neighborhood then drop in, even if your not hungry, you have to try their cocktails.

photos.caption: Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom

N0BgXkJIXHDXL82a3d3eFQ.text: I came here for Sunday brunch and it was a-OK. The venue is very nice and it was lovely to eat upstairs with the sun shining and the curtains billowing. Alas, the food was less consistent than the atmospherics. I had the watermelon + feta salad to start, which sadly was outdone by a similar dish I recently had at my work cafeteria. I will say that the crab cake I had for my second course was PURE MAGIC. There was no talking for ten minutes while I eagerly consumed this meat-cake-o-deliciousness. Expect a typical yuppie-family-brunch crowd where each table is surrounded by a corral of baby strollers.

O7fYJANys3vsyN0BLtzhIw.text: We had an amazing dinner here before seeing the Lion King across the street at the Lyceum Theater.  The three course theater menu was excellent, especially the sirloin streak! One of the best steaks I've ever eaten. And the Porn Star martini is excellent too!! Cannot recommend this restaurant highly enough!

photos.caption: Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom

YlOARpu8g6auSuKR3KterA.text: Sunday brunch here is fantastic. The pancakes, the avacado toast all delicious. Great location in Covent Garden. Reservations necessary. You won't be disappointed. Highly recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom

-NNARCeSdgf1Mn7Ybn8Dmg.text: We stopped in for lunch early on Saturday afternoon and had a lovely brunch of buckwheat pancakes and eggs benedict florentine. We sat in the bar as the restaurant was very busy and the service was very good. The food came really quickly and was good, just small portions for the price. Overall it was good but nothing special. Once again London prices just blow my socks off, but this seemed excessive for the portions sizes. So it was good but I doubt that I would come in here again.

wSBLwIcgxLpm_VjIJ71YNA.text: Perfect location and the decor is beautiful. The food itself was really good but very over priced. I had the pasta and it was deliciously Could have also complained about the portion size. If I had received more of my dish I may not have any complaints.

nGdWB-59CxKJNV_ae1X3Mg.text: I have eaten here twice now and I have loved it both times. The service is great, as is the food. I think there are certain items that are more value for money, as, items like the steak just come on their own and you have to order sides as an extra. I had salmon fishcakes on my first time dining here and they were delicious, great portion with a creamy foam and spinach. Also accompanied by generous helpings of bread which the waitress kept offering. Wine menu is fantastic and well priced. The food presentation is very pleasing as well. Especially in the deserts of which I could have eaten all of them. Second time Dining I had the chicken with quinoa and again I was pleasantly surprised by how lovely the food was. The atmosphere in the restaurant is great, candle lit up a big staircase where you are then seated in a very grand room! Great for a posh very very tasty meal but not breaking the bank with the price.

2p_c6lbEaVqlBDno49Lpqg.text: We went here for a brunch. The menu has typical brunch dishes (eggs, pancakes, toasts) and we had the avocado and tomato toast (good but nothing remarkable) and the chocolate french toast (good as well but too heavy!!). Overall it was okay but nothing that really impressed us.

photos.caption: Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom

_l8-nSBKvB2wNVx_aYqTBg.text: Popped in here for a quick drink during walk around town.  Selections for cocktails was quite good especially for aged rum. Martini was excellent and service was attentive.

cyLFTxmt8y7GhM-XGYegzQ.text: Came in for a night cap with my wife an hour before closing. We grabbed a seat and waited almost 5 minutes for the waitress to find us. Place only had 15 people across four tables present. Ordered martinis. Dirty and a vesper. When they finally came, one seemed a tad short. Finally flagged the waitress down to ask about how they make their martinis. She started to spout off what was in it. I simply asked the amount after telling me two different amounts, I finally told her I was all set. The fact she spoke minimal English as ironic given we are in England. At 11 pounds a drink, this place is a rip off. Won't ever be coming back.

photos.caption: Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom. Notice the difference !!

6RVI-cwIxHoNeYgTDWH6KA.text: Absolutely fine. That pretty much sums up my experience here. Can't say anything more positive but really I can't say anything negative either. There was nothing wrong with the venue or the food, but I was left feeling pretty "meh" about the whole experience. On arrival our coats were taken & we checked in at reception. Straight away I thought of similarly set up places like Hawksmoor & had high hopes. Upstairs our table was in the back corner so not the best. Looking at the tables and the room I felt like I was in a parish hall being used for an  event - no real atmosphere & the centre tables seemed randomly rotated to fit in. The food was nice, the coffee was terrible. My BF had steak & eggs which was literally a piece of steak with 2 eggs on top, centred on a massive empty plate. I had the mushrooms & then pancakes. All in all pretty underwhelming but not horrible by any means. The staff were pleasantly aloof.  At £65 for brunch for two people I'd expect to walk away feeling stuffed & singing a places praises but not so in this case. There are plenty of other, more exciting options for brunch in London so I don't think I'll be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom. Blueberry & maple pancakes
Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom. Wild mushrooms, caramelised onions on walnut bread

BRzfqj1Q8MbXn4ZM7sZBsg.text: Came here for brunch on a Sunday morning after seeing the decent reviews on yelp, and I have to say I was really underwhelmed by it. When we first arrived, we were seated down by the window, which was lovely with the sun shining through, and I thought wow this place is fancier than I had expected. However, that facade faded almost immediately after we settled down. Maybe I caught them on a bad day, but I felt like they were just trying really hard to make the restaurant posh and the service was so sloppy that it was just not up to scratch. The food was decent, but the portion was quite small, and given the sloppy service, I could not justify paying so much for the experience. Balthazar was much better.

sGJAyyqlgrErbfnCdSq53w.text: Very cool bar!  Ambiance is great, drinks are good, not to loud, great place to meet friends.

pgzaRAa6w8FPJm-uwKn6BA.text: What a disappointment! Terrible customer service!! I needed to cancel my reservation called 23hs ahead and for my surprise they said no since was 1 hour passed the cut off time. Most  places would have understood since it was secured with a corporate card and was meant for a dinner meeting. What I know is, my company will never book there again. Thanks for nothing "manager"

zUKBL5hYo2Qgm67kJEsaJA.text: Gorgeous dining room and our Thanksgiving meal was excellent, however the staff is another story, horrible. Drinks and wine took so long, no eye contact. Staff not  personable, probably because no one speaks English here, all foreigners. The waitstaff really need to engage and not be clone/zombie like. Employees work more cafeteria style than a fine dining room.

jcvvBTPl4gs2LLmAFW5ZJA.text: My husband and I had lunch at Christopher's a few Sundays ago...here are my thoughts:Ambiance: Christopher's is beautiful, inside and out. I loved the classy and clean décor. Service: Top notch. Servers were friendly and food came out quickly.Food: Crabcakes were delicious. Avoid the house salad, which is nothing special (although the dressing was quite tasty). My husband had the Huevos California, which were too greasy for my taste. Not quite what we expected (especially since we're originally from California), and he didn't eat too much of it.Overall: I would definitely return to Christopher's on my next visit to London. I highly recommend it.

gA60ErykWMIeFslm6lMwhQ.text: Stopped in late evening for a drink. Excellent martinis and cocktails.  Nice ambiance,  and good service.

C7akiACuADhzhfcvEoAh-A.text: Just came here for a drink...... Or two.  We were greeted by lovely staff who ushered us to our seat, shortly after we greeted by our waiter who was polite and helped with our drinks selections. Excellent staff plus amazing selections of martinis and cocktail equals susess. This was my first visit here; Now that I've found this place, it won't be the last.

Sseh21Lq0Gd5284ddDOqDg.text: I visited the martini bar and was so impressed. Lost for choice over the cocktail menu, the staff were very helpful, and not so expensive prices. I went for the apple pie martini with the almond Madeleine. It was dessert in a liquid, not too overpowering with the cinnamon, nice subtle flavours. Very drinkable too!! Great service, and great mini bar food too.

photos.caption: Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom. Apple pie martini with almond madeleine

8n3D6gMNQyrar_X1l680Zw.text: Was taken to Christophers for a birthday treat. From the start to the finish the service was ace! We were greeted on the ground floor- (entrance) where our coats were taken from us. When we arrived upstairs, we were seated promptly. The decor is classy and elegant. I had salmon cakes which were very tasty and sweet potato fries. The dessert was absolutely delicious although it didn't look like there was much on the plate. Would recommend if you are looking for a classy night out for dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Christopher's - London, United Kingdom

as-W7Ty68wn_zaEpfSz6TQ.text: I've reviewed this place twice now and both times are for the cocktail bar only, which does do some rather tasty libations (I've obviously been frequenting Mr Fogg's too much recently as libation is my word of choice this week!). I've always told myself to make sure to come here and sample the food on a special occasion. Guess what, guys?! I finally made it! Upstairs in their restaurant I treated a couple of friends to a posh dinner to celebrate a works promotion for one and comiserate a really tough week for another - tough week and only Wednesday, not good!Firstly, booking. No problems here, we were straight in at the time we wanted. I then phoned up to enquire about booking pre-dinner drinks and was helpfully booked in. Then we were late and didn't make the drinks, so I felt a bit bad about that.But we arrived, were treated to the free cloakroom and shown to our table. My friends didn't know where we were going and I don't think they expected an upmarket restaurant like this one, more something cheap and cheerful. So they were happy already!We ordered a lovely bottle of crisp pinot grigio (£22 was a fair price for this in a restaurant) as we had all decided on mains of either fish or chicken. 2 of us plumped for the blackened salmon with a tomato-based risotto and the third chicken with what looked like a puy lentil side offering. £18-19 each for these dishes so we expected some good food here. Side dishes (which you paid more for) were sweet potato chips and a green vegetable mix.Bread to start, good selection of different flavours here. The butter was nicely mixed with herbs but was too hard, I think it should have been taken out of the fridge a bit earlier. Then the mains arrived - the salmon was soft and tasty but a little bit overcooked, I was hoping for it be slightly pinker in the middle. But it flaked well and the blackened crust was a really nice touch. The risotto side was nice (a bit stodgy) but the side salad took the edge of that with a really refreshing dressing. My friend made all sorts of yummy noises at the chicken - she was quite loud so tables did start to peer over!The side dishes were perfect - crispy sweet potato and salty greens of al dente broccolini, mange tout and sandfire. A bit too al dente for me but I do like my greens done a bit longer than most. So all in all, at £21 ish per person for mains we were satisfied. A bit overpriced perhaps.Then the desserts came round. We decided to be naughty - why not, it was Wednesday right?! We ordered 3 and split them, brilliant plan since I love sharing food and trying little bits of everything. First was creme brulee - slightly burnt top but really mellow flavour underneath, complimented with a berry summer pudding - refreshing and fruity. Second a beautiful banana tarte tartin, sounds like it shouldn't work but it did! wonderful sweet and sticky sauce over this one, decadent and rich. Served with a smooth vanilla ice cream and a chocolate brownie to add a bit more naughty to this dish. Then finally (and I mean Oh My God!) was a chocolate and peanut butter tart with a caramel sauce and espresso ice cream. Now you have just named all of my favourite foods right there and this thing was divine! All of the yummy noises came from our table at that point. Very filling, but rich and deep in flavour with the coffee kick from the ice cream simply snapped you out of your chocolatey,'eyes glazing over' food coma. That thing was divine. £7 or £8 each, more than worth that price!So overall, 4 stars. Friendly staff (if a little slow) they always kept the wine topped up and were courteous and helpful. Just a slightly disappointing main (in comparison with the dessert), I left happy and content.

plX-Soz_ggzt2BN7UvqXkQ.text: Excellent food and the Martini's were superb. Great post theatre eatery. Not too sure about the automatic 12.5% service, you might be American but we Brits like to decide our own tips.
